title: 112_hr6427
content: The Act titled "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" establishes a Job Training Resources Grant Program. The "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" establishes a Job Training Resources Grant Program under Section 403(a) of the Social Security Act. This program provides grants for the purchase, renovation, construction, or lease of real property for qualified self-sustaining job programs. The term 'qualified self-sustaining job program' refers to a program that offers job training and placement services to individuals with employment challenges, without requiring federal funds for programmatic or administrative expenses. The Secretary gives priority to eligible applicants with successful experience in establishing self-sustaining job programs or with local membership. The eligible applicant for grants must be a national organization described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, focused on providing employment-related services to individuals. The grant conditions for eligible applicants include job placement performance goals established by the Secretary in coordination with the grantee. The grantee must meet job placement performance goals for each self-sustaining job program funded by the grant, with assessment dates set by the Secretary. The Secretary will measure the achievement of goals set for real property purchased, renovated, constructed, or improved using funds from the grant. The Secretary will ensure the protection of the Federal Government's interest in the property as prescribed. Out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated, funds under this paragraph shall be distributed among local member organizations for self-sustaining job programs. Appropriated $200,000,000 for grants for fiscal year 2013 under this paragraph, to remain available through fiscal year 2016. Amended Social Security Act to include penalty for failure to meet job placement goals in self-sustaining job programs. If a recipient of funds fails to meet job placement goals, repayment to the Treasury is required over a 10-year period starting from the date of failure. If a recipient of funds fails to meet job placement goals, repayment to the Treasury is required over a 10-year period starting from the date of failure. The recipient may elect to comply with job placement goals instead of making payments, with the Secretary's consent. Compliance must be demonstrated as prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary may reduce grants to a State subject to a penalty instead of requiring payments, over a 10-year period. State penalty limitations do not apply in this case. The Social Security Act is amended to exclude penalties under certain circumstances. The Social Security Act is amended to exclude penalties under certain circumstances. Offset to ensure PAYGO compliance.
